item.title: Pypismplot
item.description:
Get source code from Github

Plot PISM data using matplotlib and netcdf4-python

item.title: Glacial erosion in orogenic belts
item.description:
Why

Glacial erosion is a key component linking climate, tectonics and surface processes. Previous study has proposed a theory that glacial erosion can provide both destructive and constructive controls on mountain building. Warm-based glaciers have fast basal sliding rates and usually have higher erosion power than fluvial processes. Code-based glaciers, however, have slow basal sliding rate and lower erosion power. Therefore, warm-based glaciers can limit mountain heights by erosion and cold-based glaciers can protect mountains from erosion. My research aims to test this theory using numerical models.

How

I conduct a series of numerical experiments to simulate the glaciation in a steady-state mountain belt using Parallel Ice Sheet Model (PISM). The bedrock topography is a synthetic fluvial landscape in steady state, representing typical pre-glaciation landscapes. The experiments cover a range of various climatic conditions represented by different values of mean annual sea-level temperature and mean annual precipitation. The erosion rate is estimated by a linear erosion law that the erosion rate is proportional to the basal sliding velocity.

What I learn

Preliminary analysis of the results shows that when the ELAs in different runs are similar, the glaciers in colder climate conditions have lower total erosion. This finding is consistent with the hypothesis.

If you want to learn more about this research, contact me.

item.title: Post-glacial landscape evolution
item.description:
Background

Landscapes of the US Midwest were repeatedly affected by the southernmost portions of the Laurentide Ice Sheet during the Quaternary. Over much of the Midwest, depositional glacial processes diminished pre-glacial relief by filling valleys and left constructional landforms including low-relief till plains and high relief moraines. As the ice retreated, meltwater collected in subglacial or proglacial lakes leaving fine-grained, sorted sediment in the form of glacial lake plains. Glacial lakes episodically drained in outburst floods, carving deep valleys.

However, meltwater valleys did not provide a landscape-wide integrated drainage network. Instead, a significant fraction of the area of low-relief till plains and glacial lake plains was occupied by closed depressions and remained unconnected to external drainage networks. This area is referred to by hydrologists as non-contributing area (NCA) because it does not typically contribute surface runoff to stream networks. NCA becomes integrated into external drainage networks over time.

Hypothesis

We propose that this integration could occur via at least two different paths:

  • through capture of NCA as channel heads propagate into the upland or,
  • through erosion of a channel along a flow path that, perhaps intermittently, connects NCA to the external drainage network.

We refer the two cases as “disconnected” and “connected” since the crucial difference between them is the hydrological connection of the upland to external drainage.

Method

We investigate the difference in morphology and rate of growth of channel networks in low relief landscapes under disconnected and connected drainage regimes using numerical simulations of fluvial and hillslope processes.

We use the Landlab model platform to simulate the evolution of post-glacial landscapes, starting from a flat low-relief surface. The surface evolves via detachment-limited fluvial incision and hillslope diffusion.

The model is coupled with a new flow routing algorithm that represents upland connection by spillover of water from closed depressions. The modified version of Landlab is here.

Findings

  • The growth of channel network is faster in the connected case than in the disconnected case.
  • The channel network in the connected case has longer and more sinuous channels than the disconnected case.
  • To accomplish the same degree of integration, the connected case removes less sediment than the disconnected case.
  • Holding the volumes of water constant shows that the disconnected case is more efficient than the connected case at eroding for limited volumes of accumulated discharge.

I presented this research in AGU 2017 Fall Meeting. A manuscript has been submitted to Journal of Geophysical Research: Earth Surface. If you want to learn more about this research, contact me.
